text.headline: History of Cocos Island
text.text: Cocos Island: a tropical treasure over 500km off the coast of Costa Rica. Explore its rich history in this interactive timeline.

text.headline: Discovery
text.text: Spanish sailor Juan Cabezas creates the first written record of the island.

media.caption: The map looks upside-down to us, with North at the bottom of the map.

text.headline: Put it on the map
text.text:
Cocos Island first appears on a map delivered to King Henry the II of France by cartographer Nicolas Desliens.

The original Planisphère by Nicolas Desliens is now stored at the Bibliothèque Nationale of France.

media.caption: The vast amount of caves, nooks, and crannies provide many great hiding spots for a secret treasure.

text.headline: The Treasure of Lima
text.text: The Spanish removed over $50 million of gold, diamonds, jewels, and swords from Lima, Peru. The captain of the boat carrying the treasure stole it all and headed to Cocos Island.

text.headline: First Costa Rican presence
text.text:
Costa Ricans first visited Cocos Island when President Juan Mora Fernández sent a ship to rescue a group of Chilean outcasts.

Costa Rica first claimed Cocos Island as its territory in 1869, but the claim did not become law until 1949.

media.caption: The remoteness of Cocos Island made it a great option for a prison.

text.headline: Prison island
text.text: A prison once stood on Cocos Island.

media.caption: Anastasio Alfaro (left) and Henry Pittier (right) were the first scientists to make scientific observations of life on Cocos Island.
media.credit: "Anastasio Alfaro", "Henry Pittier" (Public Domain) / Sistema Nacional de Bibliotecas

text.headline: First scientific expedition
text.text: President Rafael Yglesias sent the first scientific expedition to Cocos Island, with scientists Anastasio Alfaro and Henry Pittier.

media.credit: Image from page 359 of ”The Arcturus adv" (Public Domain) by Internet Archive Book Images

text.headline: Treasure hunter
text.text:
German citizen Augusto Gissler lived on the island treasure hunting. He installed himself there with 13 families.

Augusto was searching for the Treasure of Lima. In his 19 years living there, he only found 6 gold coins. The remains of his home can still be found there.

media.caption: Cocos Island is one of eleven Conservation Areas in Costa Rica.
media.credit: my domicile for 15 days" (CC BY 2.0) by jonrawlinson

text.headline: National Park
text.text: President Rodrigo Carazo declares Cocos Island a National Park.

text.headline: World Heritage Site
text.text:
Cocos Island becomes a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Cocos Island was deemed to have scientific and cultural significance by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Now it is protected by international treaties.

text.headline: Wetland of International Importance
text.text:
The area is declared as a Wetland of International Importance under the Convention on Wetlands, an international treaty for conservation and sustainable use of wetlands.

Cocos Island is a key habitat for hundreds of bird species. Some of these birds are endemic to the island, which means they are only found there.

media.caption: Costa Rica will continue to protect Cocos Island for generations to come.

text.headline: Historic and Cultural Site
text.text: Cocos Island is declared a Historic and Cultural Site by the Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports of Costa Rica.
